questions.question: Why did the Greeks attack Troy? (Variant 51)
questions.answer: Because Paris carried away Helen.

questions.question: Who ruled Troy during the war? (Variant 52)
questions.answer: King Priam was the ruler of Troy.

questions.question: Why was Achilles angry? (Variant 53)
questions.answer: Because his honour was insulted.

questions.question: What made Hector respected? (Variant 54)
questions.answer: His bravery and loyalty to Troy.

questions.question: What trick ended the war? (Variant 55)
questions.answer: The wooden horse filled with soldiers.

questions.answer: They thought it was a peace gift.

questions.answer: He planned the wooden horse strategy.

questions.answer: They were tricked and unprepared.

questions.question: What was Helen’s role in the conflict? (Variant 59)
questions.answer: Her capture caused the conflict.

questions.question: What lesson does the fall teach? (Variant 60)
questions.answer: Pride and deception can destroy nations.

questions.question: Explain how the dispute over Helen led to a ten‑year war. (Insight 151)
questions.answer: Helen’s capture caused Menelaus and the Greeks to wage war on Troy. Honour and reputation led to a decade-long struggle.

questions.question: Describe the bravery of Hector and Achilles during the war. (Insight 152)
questions.answer: Hector fought for his homeland with loyalty, while Achilles fought with unmatched skill, making both legendary.

questions.question: How did Odysseus’ plan change the fate of Troy? (Insight 153)
questions.answer: Odysseus used intelligence instead of weapons. The hidden soldiers in the horse led to Troy’s sudden defeat.

questions.question: Why is Troy’s downfall considered a warning in history? (Insight 154)
questions.answer: It warns that overconfidence and ignoring danger bring disaster even to strong cities.

questions.question: Explain the themes of pride, revenge and trickery in the story. (Insight 155)
questions.answer: Paris’s pride sparked revenge; brave warriors battled; yet clever deception defeated strength, showing brains win over force.
